title: 105_hr2754
content: The "Health Care Worker Protection Act of 1997" may be cited as the short title. Hospitals under the Medicare program are required to use designated hollow-bore needle devices. The Health Care Worker Protection Act of 1997 requires hospitals to use designated hollow-bore needle devices to minimize the risk of needlestick injuries to healthcare workers. The Health Care Worker Protection Act of 1997 mandates the use of specific hollow-bore needle devices in hospitals to reduce needlestick injuries. The Secretary has the authority to waive this requirement for critical access hospitals, self-administration cases, and other instances deemed appropriate. These amendments apply to hospitals using hollow-bore needle devices after the FDA designates device classes. The Health Care Worker Protection Act of 1997 mandates the use of designated hollow-bore needle devices in hospitals to reduce needlestick injuries. The Secretary has the authority to waive this requirement for certain cases. The Health Care Worker Protection Act of 1997 requires hospitals to use specific hollow-bore needle devices to minimize needlestick injuries. The Under Secretary for Health must ensure compliance with this requirement, with the option to waive it for self-administration cases. The Health Care Worker Protection Act of 1997 mandates the use of designated hollow-bore needle devices in hospitals to reduce needlestick injuries. The Under Secretary for Health can exempt self-administration cases from this requirement. The effective date for these amendments is determined by the Commissioner of Food and Drugs. Designation of classes of hollow-bore needle devices to minimize needlestick injury risk. Designation of classes of hollow-bore needle devices to minimize needlestick injury risk. The Commissioner of Food and Drugs, in consultation with an advisory council, will designate and periodically review these classes. The advisory council includes representatives from consumer groups and healthcare workers. The term "needlestick injury" is defined as the introduction of blood or infectious material into a healthcare worker's body through a hollow-bore needle device. This Act includes workers and technical experts as determined by the Commissioner. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide education and training on designated hollow-bore needle devices. $5,000,000 is authorized for this purpose.
